en.value: Where are you staying?
Discussing different types of holiday accommodation - Listening comprehension: Present tense for future use
We're staying in a hotel

Let's learn some handy words and phrases for when booking holiday accommodation. We'll follow the story of a couple going on holiday. Listen carefully to the audios and use the transcriptions to help you.
Here's a tip!
Listen to the audio.
Memorise the word(s).
In the audio, Helena tells her boyfriend about a great place she has seen online. Here's the transcript of their conversation. Pay special attention to the words in bold.
Viktor, look! I found the perfect place to stay in! It's a five-star hotel on the top of a mountain. We can look at the stars at night - so romantic!
It looks great! Why don't you reserve a room?
Ok, I'm making a reservation now: check in is April 29th, check out is the next day at 11am.
I hope breakfast is included: the views from the restaurant must be stunning!
Here's the translation!
What's the meaning of "to stay at a hotel" ?
to have a room in a hotel
to reserve a room in a hotel
to travel to a hotel
to stay at
We stayed at some really cool hostels while we were travelling through Europe.
We'll stay [k]in[/k] hostels while we're travelling through Europe.
to
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Where are you? - I'm at the hotel waiting for you!
Where are you? - I'm in the hotel taking a nap.

We can say "to stay at a hotel / hostel, etc." or "to stay in a hotel / hostel, etc." and they're both correct. The only difference in some contexts is that we use "in" to imply that we are inside the hotel, and we can use "at" even when we are outside / near the hotel.
to stay for
How long are you staying for?
We are staying [k]for[/k] three days.
at
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
expresses time
expresses place
My friends are staying for a week.
My friends are staying at the hotel.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
My friends are staying.
to get a room
Could we get a double room, please?
to make a reservation
We made a reservation online under the name "Baker".
Complete the sentence: Should we ... a room for two nights?
get
go
make
We made a [k]r[/k]e[k]s[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k][k]v[/k]a[k]t[/k][k]i[/k]o[k]n[/k] online under the name "Baker".
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
As we just saw, we can say "to make a reservation", or we can just use the verb "to reserve". Have a look at the following examples.
I have reserved a three-bed room in a cosy hotel.
I have made a reservation for a three-bed room in a cosy hotel.
[k]I have[/k] [k]made[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]reservation[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]a three-bed room[/k] [k]in a cosy[/k] [k]hotel[/k].
Select the words in the correct order.
to check in
We can check in after 2pm.
to check out
We have to check out before 12 midday.
check in
check out
When we arrive at the hotel.
When we leave the hotel.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Our plane arrives at 12 but we can't check [k]in[/k] before 2pm.
out
fully-booked
I tried to book a villa, but they were fully-booked.

Cheap, handy hostel? 5-star hotel? Luxury villa? Cosy bed and breakfast? Campsite under the stars? Where are you going to stay? Here's a short list of the different types of accommodation we might stay in.
Hotel, 5-star hotel: I can't believe we got a room in a luxury 5-star hotel!
Hostel: We'll check in at the hostel at 12.
Bed and breakfast (B&B, for short): This B&B has the best fry up in Edinburgh!
Campsite: This campsite has great facilities.
What do we say when there are no rooms available in a hotel?
it's fully-booked
it's full of books
it's fullfiled
Remember Helena and her boyfriend, who were booking a room in a hotel? Let's listen to Helena telling her friend Bea what happened next!
Listen to the audio.
Which of the following better summarises Helena's "romantic" getaway?
Helena got a double room at a 5-star hotel. Check in was at 12.
Helena tried to book a 5-star hotel but it was fully-booked.
Helena made a reservation and got a single room in a hotel.
Select all the places where we can stay.
This [h]b&b[/h] has the best fry up in Edinburgh!
This [h]campsite[/h] has great facilities.
We'll check in at the [h]hostel[/h] at 12.
What does Helena decide to do next time?
stay at a campsite
check out at 12
reserve a B&B
The hotel where we wanted to go was fully-[k]booked[/k].
book
Which of the following expressions tell us how long you stay at your accommodation?
stay for
stay in
stay at
I have [k]reserved[/k] a three-bed [k]room[/k] in a cosy hotel.
make
reservation
Now listen to Helena and her boyfriend talking about their future holiday plans.
Listen to the audio. Which statement is most accurate?
Helena reserved a room in a cosy bed and breakfast.
Helena reserved a bed in a hostel with breakfast.
Helena reserved a bed in a 5-star hotel with great views.
I've [k]got|reserved|booked[/k] a room at a cosy bed and breakfast.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
We couldn't get a room, the hotel was fully-[k]booked[/k].
Type the correct word.
Select the correct definition.
to check in
to check out
arrive and register at your accommodation
leave your accommodation
Select the correct ending of the sentence.
We're staying in
We're staying for
a hotel for three nights.
three nights in a hotel.
How long are you staying [k]for[/k]?
Complete the sentence with the correct preposition.
I have made a [k]reservation[/k] for a three-bed room in a cosy hotel.
reserved
I have [k]reserved|booked[/k] a three-bed room.
Present perfect
My friend Liz has [k]got a room[/k] for us in a hostel.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I would love to stay [k]in|at|on[/k] a campsite!
Select the preposition that goes after "stay" in this context.
to stay in / at
to stay for
to get / to reserve a room
fully-booked
to make a reservation
to check in
to check out
Here's a recap of the expressions we've learned in this unit:
And here are the types of accommodations we've learned:
hotel, 5-star hotel
hostel
campsite
bed and breakfast (B&B)
Do you prefer luxury hotels or budget-friendly hostels? Which is more important - a comfortable bed or a hearty breakfast? Share your views with the busuu community!
I like hostels because ... / Next month I'm staying in a ... / I love the breakfast at ... / I think camping is ...
When is your next trip?

We have already learned that we can use present tenses to talk about things in the future. Now we will focus on listening to these in action! Listen carefully to the audios and as many times as you need. At the end of the activity you will see the written translation!
Listen to the audio.
What are Justin and Lisa's plans?
They're going on holiday.
They're going to work hard.
They're going for dinner.
True or false?
They have already gone on holiday.
They are going next month.
Listen to the audio and select the correct answer.
They will be flying out on the 15th.
They are not sure when they will be flying out.
They aren't flying out on the 15th.
He is asking where they stayed.
He is asking where they will stay.
That sounds lovely, where are you [k]staying[/k]?
Select all the verbs.
Justin and I [h]are[/h] [h]going[/h] on holiday to Italy next month, and I [h]am[/h] [h]looking[/h] forward to it!

Lisa: Justin and I are going on holiday to Italy next month, and I am looking forward to it! 
Max: That sounds lovely, where are you staying? 
Lisa: We booked a lovely boutique hotel by the beach! Then we are travelling down the coast.
Max: You two really deserve this trip, you work so hard! 
Lisa: Thank you! We fly out on the 15th, maybe we can go for a coffee before we leave.
Listen to the audio.
What are Petra's plans?
She's going on an adventure.
She's going home.
She's taking work seriously.
Petra has already gone on her holiday.
Petra is still planning it.
Listen to the audio and select the correct answer.
Petra is going to pack a bag.
Petra has packed a bag.
Petra will not pack a bag.
I am [k]taking[/k] some time off this summer and planning a getaway.
I'm [k]packing[/k] a small bag and [k]going[/k] on an adventure!
packed
went
Petra is reserving hostel rooms for her future trip.
I am taking some time off this summer and planning a getaway. I'm packing a small bag and going on an adventure! I am so excited, I'm reserving hostel rooms already! (translation)
Listen to the audio.
Listen to the audio.
What are Anja and Trevor's plans?
They are going on a trip soon.
They have booked a cruise.
They are looking to book a trip.
Listen to the audio. What does Anja talk about?
Anja is talking about when they will arrive in the future.
Anja is talking about arriving right now.
Anja is talking about having arrived already.
Hope there are no problems when we [k]check in[/k] to the hotel.
They have already taken a cruise.
They will take a cruise.
Select the words Trevor uses to ask about the time they arrive at the hotel.
I am very much looking forward to our trip. [h]When[/h] [h]do[/h] [h]we[/h] [h]get[/h] [h]in[/h]?
We [k]arrive[/k] at 11, if our flights aren't delayed.
arrived

Trevor: I'm really looking forward to our trip. When do we get in? 
Anja: We arrive at 10 p.m. if our flights aren't delayed.
Trevor: Hopefully there are no problems when we check in to the hotel. 
Anja: I doubt it. They know our flight arrives late.
Trevor: Next year we are taking a cruise, that will be even more relaxing!
